title: How to Install Bamboo Flooring on Stairs

steps.headline: Pull up any floor covering like carpeting.
steps.description: Don't install the bamboo over any type of floor covering. Pull up any carpet or wooden planks that you currently have on the steps to make room for the bamboo.If the stairs are bare already, then you can skip this step. If you do remove carpeting, there may be staples or flooring nails leftover. Make sure to remove all of these as well.

steps.headline: Clean and vacuum the staircase to remove dust.
steps.description: Trapped dust and dirt can damage the bamboo flooring. Go over the staircase with a vacuum to remove any debris. Then, wipe down each step with a wet rag to get anything that the vacuum missed.Be sure to clean the risers as well, and get into any cracks or crevices that the vacuum could've missed. If there is leftover residue from glue, use a wood cleaner or mineral spirits to remove it before laying the bamboo.

steps.headline: Remove or drive down any screws and nails sticking up.
steps.description: Check the staircase thoroughly for obstructions like these. If you see any nails sticking up, use a hammer and nail set to drive them below the surface, or pull them out with the hammer teeth. For screws, use a power drill to drive them down all the way or run it in reverse to remove them.Store any nails or screws you remove in a safe place so no one steps on them.

steps.headline: Get a bamboo flooring kit that includes stair noses.
steps.description: Stair noses are rounded ends that go along the edges of each step. If you’re buying bamboo flooring, look for a kit that includes noses. Otherwise, buy a separate kit for noses along with the normal flooring.If you buy stair noses individually, you have 2 choices. One type overlaps the planks and has a slight rise. The other sits flush with the planks. Consider which type you prefer. Find stair noses that match the color and texture of the flooring planks. Otherwise, the design will be inconsistent. Wear gloves whenever you handle the bamboo pieces. They’re very smooth on the top, but rough on the sides and bottom, so you could get splinters if you use your bare hands.

steps.headline: Measure the length and width of the steps you’re covering.
steps.description: Use your tape measure and start by taking the length of the step. Then measure the width of the step from the front edge to the back riser. Write these measurements down so you don’t forget.The measurements for each step should be equal, but double-check to make sure. Construction isn't always exact, and wood can warp over time.

steps.headline: Calculate how many planks will fit on each step.
steps.description: Take the width of the planks and divide it into the width of the step. Then add the amount of space you need for the nose. The result is how many planks can fit onto each step.For example, if the step is 12 inches (30 cm) wide and the planks are 5 inches (13 cm) wide, then the step can fit 2 planks and has 2 inches (5.1 cm) for the nose. The planks may not evenly fit into the step. For instance, if the steps were 14 inches (36 cm), each plank was 5 inches (13 cm), and you needed 2 inches (5.1 cm) for the nose, you’d have 2 inches (5.1 cm) leftover. In this case, you can cut a plank to fill the leftover space. In most cases, the planks will be too long for the steps and have to be cut. However, if you have short planks or long stairs, run the same calculation to determine how many you need to stretch across the step.

steps.headline: Mark the cutting lines on the floor planks and noses.
steps.description: Measure the planks to the correct length to fit across your steps. Use a pencil and straightedge to make a cutting line. Do this on each piece of bamboo you have to cut.If the planks are 36 inches (91 cm) long and your steps are 24 inches (61 cm), measure to the 24 in (61 cm) mark. Make a line at this point.

steps.headline: Cut the planks and noses to the correct length.
steps.description: Bring the planks to your power saw and align the blade with the cutting line. Power the saw on, then press it into the wood with even pressure until you cut entirely through the piece. Cut along the line on each plank and nose.You can use several different saws for this job, but the easiest would be a circular saw or miter saw. If you use a circular saw, work on a sawhorse for extra safety. A carbide blade cuts through bamboo much easier than a non-carbide blade. Always wear gloves and goggles when operating a power saw. Keep your hands at least 6 inches (15 cm) away from the blade while it’s spinning.

steps.headline: Split the planks longways if whole planks won’t fit.
steps.description: If the bamboo planks don’t fit evenly onto the steps, you’ll have to cut them to size. Divide the width of 1 plank into the total width of the step. If you get a remainder, that’s how thick a plank has to be to cover the whole step. Make a straight line across the plank lengthwise at this point. Then cut the plank along this line.If the steps were 14 inches (36 cm), each plank was 5 inches (13 cm), and you needed 2 inches (5.1 cm) for the nose, then cut 3 inches (7.6 cm) off one plank. If you have a table saw, splitting wood longways is much easier. If not, you’ll probably have to make multiple cuts to get all the way across.

steps.headline: Lay the thinnest panel against the back of the step.
steps.description: If you cut any panels lengthwise, lay these down first. Press them down and make them even with the step riser.If you didn’t cut any of the pieces lengthwise, then start with any whole piece along the back portion.

steps.headline: Drill pilot holes every 6 inches (15 cm) along the plank.
steps.description: Nailing directly into bamboo can split it, so drill holes first. Drill one hole at the far end of the plank, near its center. Continue working across the plank in 6 in (15 cm) increments.If you have a nail gun, it should drive the nails through the bamboo without splitting it, so you can also use this. Try to make the holes as equally-spaced as possible.

steps.headline: Drive finishing nails into each pilot hole.
steps.description: Insert a finishing nail into the pilot hole. Then tap it down with a hammer. Use a nail set to finish the nail. Repeat this process for each hole you drilled.A finishing nail is a thin type of nail with a smaller head. They come in various lengths. 1–2 inches (2.5–5.1 cm) should be perfect for this job.

steps.headline: Snap the next plank underneath the first one if a second one will fit.
steps.description: Bamboo planks have snap attachments to hold them together. Take the second plank and tuck the snap section under the first plank. Press down to secure it in place.For extra security, you can apply a thin line of wood glue along the snap section to keep the planks attached.

steps.headline: Nail the plank down.
steps.description: Follow the same procedure for nailing this plank down. Drill pilot holes every 6 inches (15 cm) and drive finishing nails down to secure the plank.If the step is thick enough for more than 2 planks, then continue with this process until you reach the spot for the nose.

steps.headline: Attach the nose along the edge of the step.
steps.description: Take the nose and press it onto the edge of the step. Then nail it down the same way you attached the planks.If you don’t like seeing the nails in the bamboo, you can fill the holes with putty when you’re done.

steps.headline: Add horizontal planks for the stair risers.
steps.description: The risers are the back parts of the stairs. If you want to cover them with bamboo as well, follow the same procedure for measuring and cutting the planks to the correct size. Then hold a plank against the riser and drill holes through it. Finally, hammer finishing nails in to attach it. Repeat this process to cover each riser.If you have trouble hammering horizontally, you can alternatively attach the planks with glue instead. This is an optional step only if you want the entire staircase covered in bamboo. Some people prefer to leave the risers uncovered for a different type of decoration.
